message: I don't read many novels but not too long ago I read This Present Darkness which I liked a lot.

I've only read a few, visitation by that guy that writes this present darkness... whatever his name is... and red, white, black by that other guy i forget. finally i have read about 3/4 of the left behind series.
@LintonCaldecott Frank Peretti
So what novels have you guys read that stand out :)
i've not read frank peretti, who writes that?
I ordered "Black/Red/White (The Circle Trilogy 1-3)" by Ted Dekker. Sure I'll get to it one of these days :)
I read 'the Shack'.

@EdwinGarden Yeah, that's what I've heard. It's a book filled with good feeling and tears. The other side is the people that are annoyed that the "Jesus" character can't catch a fish, enjoys a good fart etc.
Hey I like the bell noise!
@EdwinGarden And what you think? I heard it kicked up quite a storm. Many loved it. Many hated it.

@penkin No sorry man.. Just joking. I was chatting to some guy on the Emmaus weekend who didn't mind admitting to producing bucketloads of man-tears when reading it.. I stay away from that junk man! Almost as bad as Disney movies..
Lunch is served!
@EdwinGarden all in the name of fiction. There was an interview with the author and he said it did not matter if it diminishes God's character because it's just fiction.
@EdwinGarden Oh, and *ding* :D
the shack is HERESY!

The Shack is interesting. It's biggest failure is that it was written as if it was factual without a clear enough disclaimer of it's fiction. So many people read it as a factual story which it was never meant to be. It challenges many of our perceptions of God but for many, myself included, pushes a little too far into eastern mysticism.
Black/Red/White is cool. I also have the Lamb amongst the stars which is interesting.
@pevans_om "Lamb amongst the stars", was it good? I was looking at getting that. Did you read all three? I have them in my Amazon wishlist :) Just need to finish my other books first.
@pevans_om Unless you say it's super amazing and I need to read it next that is :D

@penkin Mine is actually 4 because the current 1st book was originally 2 books. I have read them all. The are good. Ending is a little disappointing, but still and interesting perspective on the struggle with and effects of sin

here's something about novels. There is a massive tendency to read novels for hundreds of hours on end, not read scripture... so there is gigantic momentum toward the opinions of the more literarily adept, and a giant illiteracy  when it comes to what the bible actually says.
@LintonCaldecott Nope, don't think I read that one.
Did they make a book after the Potter movies?
so deep.
and scripturally and biblically relevant too!
Harry Potter rocks...
How much of what we believe comes from stories or people or sermons and how much is rooted in scripture?
@pevans_om Haven't read that one either

@pevans_om walk around cum books or gospel direct, I recon much (most?) of what people (me?) believe is second or third hand... Though I'm not the worst at finding out for myself... Certainly not active enough at it though.

Not exactly a Novel, but Nicole is reading this book - The Devil in Pew Number Seven - http://www.amazon.com/Devil-Pew-Number-Seven/dp/1414326599 - and she was telling me about it. Super crazy. This paster is hired by a church and there is a dude who is not a member but he is part of the elders and he basically holds everyone in the town in fear. He tries to kill the paster for taking away his eldership (or control of the church) and finally succeeds in killing the wife after a few attempts over 5 years with bombs and assassins. Crazy stuff and according to the author who is the daugher, it's all true. Man alive.
Should this be in "Religious Interference"? :)

A few worth reading that aren't novels: Through Gates of Splendour (Must read!) , The Bible or the Axe. My Big Father. There are more, but I can't think of the titles now. They're all stories of real life missionaries
